world_news:
• Hunter Biden Convicted: A Delaware jury found Hunter Biden, son of U.S. President Joe Biden, guilty on all three felony charges related to illegally purchasing a firearm while being a drug user, a historic first conviction for the child of a sitting president.
  • UN Security Council Endorses Gaza Ceasefire Plan: The UN Security Council passed a U.S.-drafted resolution backing a three-phase ceasefire plan to end the war in Gaza. The resolution calls on Hamas to accept the deal, which Israel has reportedly already agreed to.
  • Malawi Vice President Killed in Plane Crash: Malawi's Vice President, Saulos Chilima, and nine other individuals were killed after the military aircraft they were on crashed in a mountainous forest area. There were no survivors.
  • Blinken in Middle East to Push Ceasefire: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken is meeting with regional leaders to advance the Gaza ceasefire proposal, stating that a positive response from Hamas would be the most effective way to protect civilians and get more aid delivered.
  • French Left-Wing Parties Form Alliance: In response to President Macron's call for a snap election, France's Socialists, Greens, Communists, and the hard-left France Unbowed party have agreed to form a 'Popular Front' coalition to challenge the surging far-right.
  • Ukraine Claims Strikes on Russian Air Defenses in Crimea: Kyiv's military reported successful overnight strikes on Russian S-400 and S-300 anti-aircraft missile systems in several locations across occupied Crimea, aiming to weaken Russia's air defense network.
  • Apple Unveils 'Apple Intelligence' AI System: Apple announced its new AI platform, 'Apple Intelligence,' which will be integrated into its operating systems. The system will offer features like text summarization and image generation, and will incorporate OpenAI's ChatGPT.
  • Four Israeli Hostages Confirmed Dead: The Israeli military confirmed the deaths of four more hostages who were held by Hamas in Gaza. The army stated they were killed together during an operation in Khan Younis several months ago.
  • Houthi Rebels Arrest UN and Aid Workers: Yemen's Houthi rebels have detained at least 11 United Nations personnel and numerous staff from other aid organizations, accusing them of being part of an American-Israeli 'spy network.'
  • World Bank Raises Global Growth Forecast: The World Bank slightly upgraded its 2024 global economic growth forecast to 2.6%, citing the strength of the U.S. economy. However, it warned that the world's poorest countries are still struggling with instability and high debt.
us_news:
• DOJ Sues Ticketmaster: The Department of Justice, along with 30 states, filed a major antitrust lawsuit against Live Nation Entertainment and its subsidiary Ticketmaster, accusing them of running an illegal monopoly over the live music industry and seeking to break up the company.
  • Alito Flag Controversy: Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito is facing calls from Democrats to recuse himself from cases related to the 2020 election after a report that an upside-down American flag, a symbol associated with the 'Stop the Steal' movement, was flown at his home after the Jan. 6 Capitol attack.
  • Biden Cancels More Student Debt: The White House announced it is canceling another $7.7 billion in federal student loans for 160,500 borrowers through various programs, including Public Service Loan Forgiveness and income-driven repayment plans.
  • Trump Trial Nears Conclusion: The defense has rested its case in Donald Trump's New York hush money trial without the former president testifying. Closing arguments are now scheduled to take place on Tuesday, after the Memorial Day weekend.
  • Severe Weather Hits Central US: A series of powerful storms and tornadoes have devastated communities across the central and southern U.S., particularly in Iowa, Texas, and Oklahoma, causing multiple fatalities and widespread destruction.
  • RFK Jr. Fails to Qualify for CNN Debate: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. did not meet the polling and ballot access criteria set by CNN to participate in the first presidential debate on June 27, which will feature only President Joe Biden and Donald Trump.
  • US Gaza Aid Pier Faces Challenges: The newly operational U.S. military pier built to deliver humanitarian aid to Gaza is facing significant logistical hurdles and security concerns, with reports of crowds overwhelming initial truck convoys and slowing down distribution.
  • US Business Activity Accelerates: A key economic indicator showed U.S. business activity in May accelerated at the fastest pace in two years, driven by the service sector, though it also signaled a rise in prices for goods and services, complicating the Federal Reserve's inflation fight.
  • FAA Chief on Boeing Oversight: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration stated that the agency has been 'too hands-off' in its oversight of Boeing prior to a January incident where a door panel blew off a 737 MAX jet, vowing much stricter supervision going forward.
  • P. Diddy Accused of New Assault: A new lawsuit has been filed against Sean 'Diddy' Combs by a former model, Crystal McKinney, who alleges he drugged and sexually assaulted her in 2003, adding to the growing number of legal challenges facing the music mogul.
tech_news:
• Microsoft's Copilot+ PCs: At its Build conference, Microsoft unveiled a new category of AI-powered computers called Copilot+ PCs, featuring new silicon from Qualcomm and deep integration of AI into the Windows 11 operating system.
  • OpenAI Pauses 'Sky' Voice: OpenAI has paused the use of one of its GPT-4o voices, named 'Sky,' after users noted its striking similarity to Scarlett Johansson's voice. The actress confirmed she had previously declined an offer from OpenAI, prompting a public dispute.
  • Google's AI Search Errors: Google's new AI Overviews feature in its search engine is under scrutiny for providing bizarre and sometimes dangerous answers, such as suggesting users put glue on pizza or eat rocks.
  • Apple Releases iOS 17.5.1: Apple has pushed an emergency update, iOS 17.5.1, to fix a significant bug that caused some users' old, deleted photos to reappear in their photo libraries.
  • Nvidia's Blockbuster Earnings: Nvidia announced record-breaking quarterly revenue of $26 billion, a 262% increase year-over-year, driven by surging demand for its AI data center chips. The company also announced a 10-for-1 stock split.
  • EU Formally Adopts AI Act: The European Union has given final approval to its landmark AI Act, establishing the world's first comprehensive legal framework for artificial intelligence and setting a global standard for its regulation.
  • Adobe Express Update: Adobe has launched a new version of its all-in-one design app, Adobe Express, integrating its Firefly generative AI models to bring features like Text to Image and Generative Fill to a wider audience.
  • Intel Unveils 'Hala Point' AI System: Intel Labs has introduced Hala Point, the world's largest neuromorphic system, designed to support research for future brain-inspired AI and solve optimization problems with greater efficiency.
  • TikTok Algorithm Details: Facing regulatory pressure, TikTok has released new information detailing how its 'For You' recommendation algorithm works, explaining the key signals it uses to personalize user feeds.
  • Mistral AI on Azure: Microsoft announced that it is making AI models from the French startup Mistral AI available to customers through its Azure cloud computing platform, expanding its AI offerings beyond OpenAI's models.
